comment.author: 26105073@N03

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: That's much clearer now, thanks. I've just had my attention drawn to the thread and the enhanced image but while I'm on I think I can add some more information. I believe the ship is the French built and owned 4 masted barque MADELEINE 1896. MADELEINE was in the Tyne at the right sort of period, sailing from Shields to Valparaiso in 66 days in 1898. She was almost certainly employed in the Chilean nitrate trade. I've seen another photo of MADELEINE in Albert Edward Dock on the Tyne,where her name is visible and the two ships look pretty much identical. I suspect the entrance to Albert Edward Dock might be just to the left of the picture. The tug to the right is swinging MADELEINE's stern round, possibly to line her up with the dock entrance. Alternatively she may have just emerged from the dock. If that is the case, then once she has been swung, the tug on the left, which has a tow line on MADELEINE's bow, slack at the time the picture was taken, will take the strain and tow MADELEINE down river before she sets sail and makes course for Valparaiso. MADELEINE was lost in June 1911 during a severe northerly storm in the harbour of Iquique.
